benchmark_details.name: J&H: an evaluation framework for detecting the robustness of LLMs under knowledge injection attacks in the legal domain
benchmark_details.overview: This paper proposes a framework for evaluating the robustness of Large Language Models (LLMs) under knowledge injection attacks specifically in the legal domain, utilizing a syllogistic reasoning approach.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To explore whether LLMs perform deductive reasoning when accomplishing legal tasks through knowledge injection attacks.

data.size: 15,806 examples for CAIL2018 and 8,116 examples for LEVEN
data.annotation: Annotated by legal experts for legal synonyms, logical inference, and similar crime names.

methodology.calculation: PDR is calculated based on the reduction in accuracy after an attack compared to the original accuracy.
methodology.interpretation: Higher PDR indicates lower model robustness under adversarial attacks.
methodology.baseline_results: Various LLM models were evaluated, showing significant drops in performance under attacks.
methodology.validation: Robustness of LLMs was evaluated through a series of structured logical reasoning tests and knowledge injection scenarios.
